title: 55 Things to Know About Tim Walz
content:
Over at Politico, Anusha Mathur compiled 55 facts about Kamala Harrisâ€™s running mate, Minnesota governor Tim Walz. Here are some of my favorites:

3. Walz credits his rural upbringing for his values: â€œA town that small had services like that and had a public school with a government teacher that inspired me to be sitting where Iâ€™m at today. Those are real stories in small towns.â€

6. Walzâ€™s father, a school administrator, died of lung cancer when Walz was 19. Walz said this moment fueled his views on health care access: â€œThe last week of my dadâ€™s life cost my mom a decade of going back to work to pay off hospital debt.â€

9. He still speaks Mandarin.

15. He was the faculty adviser for [Mankato West High Schoolâ€™s] first gay-straight alliance chapter in 1999.

24. Walz won re-election five times in southern Minnesotaâ€™s mostly rural, conservative 1st District, serving in the House for 12 years.

28. Walz once earned an â€œAâ€ rating from the National Rifle Association and the groupâ€™s endorsement. In 2016, Guns & Ammo magazine included him on its list of top 20 politicians for gun owners.

29. He later denounced the NRA and supported gun-control measures, such as an assault weapons ban. During his first campaign for governor in 2018, the NRA completely downgraded his rating. â€œI had an A rating from the NRA. Now I get straight Fâ€™s. And I sleep just fine.â€

33. Walz frequently defends his policies, such as the universal school meals bill signed into Minnesota law earlier this year, as common sense: â€œWhat a monster! Kids are eating and having full bellies so they can go learn and women are making their own healthcare decisions,â€ Walz said jokingly.

51. His tater tot hot dish - the unofficial dish of Minnesota - is three time champion of the Minnesota Congressional Delegation Hot Dish Off. He won in 2013, 2014 and 2016.

Klein: If a Democrat is president in 2025 and thereâ€™s a governing trifecta, what do you think Democrats should pass first? What would make the biggest difference for people?

Walz: I think paid family and medical leave. Weâ€™re the last nation on earth basically to not do this. It is so foundational to just basic decency and financial well-being. And I think that would start to change both finances, attitude â€” strengthen the family.

If JD Vance is right about this: that we should make it easier for families to be together, then make sure that after your childâ€™s born, that you can spend a little time with them. Thatâ€™d be a great thing.

K: Great way of also seeing who in politics is actually pro-family and who just likes to talk about it.

W: Oh, it separates people quickly.

He also reiterated this point in the interview:

â€œRight now, Minnesota is showing the country you donâ€™t win elections to bank political capital,â€ Walz said last year. â€œYou win elections to burn political capital and improve lives.â€
